Award.AwardTitle: Coastal SEES Collaborative Research: Changes in Ship-borne Introductions of Invasive Species in Coupled Natural-human Systems: Infrastructure, Global Trade, Climate and Policy
Award.AbstractNarration:
Ships deliver 90% of the world's goods and link all ports in a global network. That network confers large economic benefits to the U.S. economy, but can also cause unintentional negative side effects including air pollution, water pollution, and the introduction of harmful invasive species. Thousands of species, some of which become invasive, hitchhike in the ballast water of ships and on the hulls and other exposed surfaces of ships. The risk from invasive species differs among ports based on the number of ships visiting a port and the visiting ships' previous ports of call. This project analyzes the global shipping network to discover where the risk of invasion has been high and to identify where the risk may increase as a result of on-going changes in the shipping network. Predictions about past and future invasions will be tested by sequencing DNA extracted from water samples taken in or near ports to detect the presence of potentially invasive species. Large changes in the shipping network are being driven by creation and expansion of new ports (e.g., liquefied natural gas terminals), the expansion of the Panama Canal, changes in ballast water practices and policies (e.g., new rules from the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency and the U.S. Coast Guard, proposed agreements from the International Maritime Organization), and changes in climate (e.g., opening of Arctic shipping lanes as sea ice declines). Through a formal consultation process with stakeholders, project results about the risk of invasions will inform port managers, ship operators, and policy-makers who can identify opportunities for the most cost effective reductions in risk in order to maximize the benefits of shipping. This project will advance the science of big data networks, improve cutting-edge genetic sequencing methods for environmental samples, and increase the net benefits of shipping via improved information provided to the private sector, non-governmental organizations, and policy-makers. Broader impacts also include interdisciplinary training for undergraduate and graduate students and postdoctoral researchers, including students from the University of Puerto Rico. This project is supported as part of the National Science Foundation's Coastal Science, Engineering, and Education for Sustainability program - Coastal SEES.

An integrated team of experts in network science, engineering, economics, freshwater and marine invasion biology, genomics, and marine policy will accomplish five goals: 1) develop a Nonindigenous Species Risk Assessment and Prediction System (NIS-RAPS), using novel methods of network modeling and data fusion; 2) calibrate and test NIS-RAPS predictions about invasions using cutting-edge environmental DNA (eDNA) metagenetic methods; 3) use NIS-RAPS to simulate NIS spread under future scenarios, exploring on a global scale how changing infrastructure, global trade, climate, and policy will affect NIS spread via ballast water and biofouling; 4) evaluate the effectiveness of different policies in reducing invasions using NIS-RAPS under future scenarios; and 5) use a Management Transition Board, including national and international policy makers, to choose global change and policy scenarios, and to increase the incorporation of research results into new national and international practices and policies to reduce invasions from ballast water and biofouling.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Coastal SEES Collaborative Research: Changes in ship-borne invasions in coupled natural-human systems: infrastructure, global trade, climate and policy

Ships deliver 90% of the world?s goods by volume and link all ports in a global network. That network confers large economic benefits to the US and global economies, with unintended negative side effects including air pollution, water pollution, and the introduction of harmful species commonly known as invasive species. Thousands of species?some of which are harmful--hitchhike in the ballast water of ships and on the hulls and other exposed surfaces of ships. Our integrated team of experts in network science, engineering, economics, freshwater and marine invasion biology, genomics, and marine policy discovered that although current ballast water management policies treat every voyage the same, in fact the risk of introducing harmful species is heterogeneous.  Risks to port and coastal regions differ dramatically among voyages and respond differently to mitigation measures, depending on the natural distribution of species and the environmental conditions in the origin and destination of voyages.

We built alternative mathematical models incorporating the key features of the global spread of species by ships, and tested them against the communities of species detected from the DNA contained in water samples, i.e., environmental DNA (eDNA), from ports across the globe. We learned that the models of the shipping network that performed best against the species detected included the number of ship voyages connecting ports, especially when we incorporated indirect ?stepping-stone? transport between ports, and the environmentally similarity among ports. This contribution helps to inform other scientists and policy makers on which models are likely to be most accurate in predicting future invasions from shipping. 

Among the species shared among ports in our analysis of 22 ports, we found 58 taxa included in the World Register of Introduced Marine Species. Overall, our work confirms that species spread risks differ among ports in predictable ways, and highlights voyage-specific management as a feasible, more effective approach, to manage ship-based species invasion biosecurity risks. 

We also conducted analyses to assess alternative policies to existing policies and practices designed to reduce invasions from ballast water discharges. Specifically we compared alternative ballast treatment practices to the current one-size-fits-all practices using shipboard treatment systems to achieve standards of maximum allowable organism concentration.  Not only do different voyages pose different risks of invasions, but risk also tends to be aggregated at hub ports, e.g., Singapore (which is connected to many other ports). Our results suggest that for such hub ports, shore-based or barge-based treatment systems could be more economically efficient, and achieve higher standards of risk reduction than shipboard ballast systems.

We also focused on the Arctic to investigate the global patterns of terrestrial species invasions caused by the global shipping network, with a focus on how increased shipping through the Arctic may change trade patterns and invasion risk. The Arctic Ocean, one region where climate change has dramatically increased shipping, might particularly benefit from the adoption of alternative management practices because over the last 25 years, shipping has become more concentrated at a few ports. We determined that climate-induced Arctic shipping leads to different invasion risk profiles between trade partners. When considering risk profiles for key U.S. trade partners in Asia, we found that risk of species spread to the U.S. east coast is highest from China and Japan. Increased shipments from Hong Kong and the Philippines via the Arctic present nominally increased risk of species spread to the U.S. given low levels of terrestrial climate similarity and minor expected trade changes between the two regions.

In general, our results indicate that the United States, China, Japan, the European Union (EU nations jointly) are at greatest risk for increased spread of terrestrial species among each other given their relatively high levels of trading activity and terrestrial and marine climate similarities. While increased trade between European and Asia-Pacific countries is expected in the future, trade between Japan and the EU seems most risky for terrestrial species because of high terrestrial climate similarity between the regions. For the spread of marine species, trade between China and the EU is high risk.  

Throughout the project, our work was shaped by communication with US and international policy-makers and in turn our work informed them.
